landlord_tenant_relationship.reasoning: Complaint alleges Plaintiff is a tenant at 123 Main St and pays monthly rent; Defendant is the owner/landlord and the person to whom Plaintiff pays rent; tenancy began June 1, 2022—facts establishing a landlord-tenant relationship (see ¶¶1.1–1.2, 4.1).

act_or_omission_by_landlord.reasoning: Complaint alleges Defendant had responsibility for maintenance and security of common areas and repeatedly failed to repair the building’s main entry door after notice, including assurances he would fix it but did not—an omission by the landlord (see ¶¶4.2–4.4, 5.3).

substantial_interference.reasoning: Complaint alleges unauthorized access to the building, theft of tenants’ packages (including Plaintiff’s $120 package), and evidence of persons sleeping in the basement, and alleges these conditions substantially interfered with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment and caused fear and distress—facts supporting substantial and unreasonable interference (see ¶¶3.1, 4.5–4.6, 5.4).

causation.reasoning: Complaint alleges the lock/door defect permitted unauthorized entry, that Plaintiff repeatedly notified Defendant who failed to repair, and that the thefts and unauthorized presence occurred “as a direct result” of the defective door—alleging a causal link between the landlord’s omission and the interference (see ¶¶4.3–4.5, 4.8, 5.4).

damages.reasoning: Complaint alleges specific economic damages (stolen package ≈ $120; security expenses ≈ $200; total $320) and additional consequential damages including emotional distress and loss of use, and seeks compensatory relief—facts adequately pleading damages (see ¶¶4.5, 4.7–4.8, 6.1, 7.1).
